title: Common Denominator
text: The first step is to find the least common denominator of two rational expressions.
speech: The first step is to find the least common denominator of two rational expressions.

title: Common Denominator
text: What is the least common denominator?
speech: What is the least common denominator?
pacedSpeech: What is the least common denominator?

title: Common Denominator
text: Since we do not know the value of $$y$$, the least common multiple of the denominators is their product. So, the LCD is $$\left(y-2\right) \left(y+1\right)$$.
speech: Since we do not know the value of  y , the least common multiple of the denominators is their product. So, the LCD is  parentheses y minus 2,  times, parentheses y plus 1,  .

title: Multiplying the First Expression
text: Now we need to multiply both expressions by a factor equal to $$1$$ that makes the denominators equal to the LCD. Starting with the first expression, we can multiply $$\frac{y+3}{y+1}$$ by a factor to make the denominator $$\left(y-2\right) \left(y+1\right)$$.

Starting with the first expression, we can multiply  fraction, y plus 3, over, y plus 1,   by a factor to make the denominator  parentheses y minus 2,  times, parentheses y plus 1,  .

title: Multiplying the First Expression
text: The denominator of $$\frac{y+3}{y-2}$$ multiplied by $$y+1$$ equals $$\left(y-2\right) \left(y+1\right)$$. So, we need to multiply $$\frac{y+3}{y+1}$$ by $$\left(y+1\right) \left(y+1\right)$$.

title: Multiplying the First Expression
text: When multiplying polynomials, we need to use FOIL.
speech: When multiplying polynomials, we need to use FOIL.
pacedSpeech: When multiplying polynomials, we need to use FOIL.

title: Multiplying the First Expression
text: First, multiply the first value in each polynomial: $$y y=y^2$$. Next, multiply the outside values: $$1y=y$$. Then, multiply the inside values: $$3y=3y$$. Lastly, multiply the last values: $$3\times1=3$$. Finally, combine like terms: $$y+3y=4y$$. So, the expression reads $$y^2+4y+3$$.
speech: First, multiply the first value in each polynomial:  y y is equal to, y squared . Next, multiply the outside values:  1 y is equal to, y . Then, multiply the inside values:  3 y, is equal to, 3 y . Lastly, multiply the last values:  3 times 1 is equal to, 3 . Finally, combine like terms:  y, plus 3 y is equal to 4 y . So, the expression reads  y squared plus 4 y plus 3 .

. Lastly, multiply the last values:   3 times 1 is equal to, 3
. Finally, combine like terms:   y, plus 3 y is equal to 4 y
. So, the expression reads   y squared plus 4 y plus 3

title: Multiplying the Second Expression
text: Next, we need to multiply the second expression by a fraction to make the denominator equal to the LCD. Because the denominator of $$\frac{y-3}{y+1}$$ needs to by multiplied by $$y-2$$ to become $$\left(y-2\right) \left(y+1\right)$$, we need to $$\frac{y-3}{y+1}$$ by $$(y-2)(y-2)$$.

text: When multiplying polynomials, we need to use FOIL.

title: Multiplying the Second Expression
text: First, multiply the first value in each polynomial: $$y y=y^2$$. Next, multiply the outside values: $$1y=y$$. Then, multiply the inside values: $$3y=3y$$. Lastly, multiply the last values: $$3\times1=3$$. Finally, combine like terms: $$y+3y=4y$$. So, the expression reads $$y^2+4y+3$$.

title: Adding the Expressions
text: Because the expressions now have the same denominator, we can add the numerators to get the sum of the two expressions. We'll leave the denominator as it is, but combine the numerator's like terms.
speech: Because the expressions now have the same denominator, we can add the numerators to get the sum of the two expressions. We'll leave the denominator as it is, but combine the numerator's like terms.

title: Adding the Expressions
speech: What is  y squared plus 4 y plus 3 minus y squared minus 5 y plus 6 ?

title: Adding the Expressions
speech: Combine the like terms:  y squared minus y squared, is equal to 0 colon   4 y, plus 5 y is equal to 9 y colon,   3 minus 6, is equal to negative 3 .

title: Final Expression
text: Now we have our final expression: $$\frac{2y^2-y+9}{\left(y-2\right) \left(y+1\right)}$$.
